title: Room 2: Compound lab
description: You move into a cold storage lab with vials labeled only with codes: THM-001, HAA-004,… You need to identify these compounds and what they do. The system only accepts correct classifications, mistakes could cause a chemical spill!

questions.question: Which of these is a common type of DBP found in tap water?
questions.explanation: THMs are among the most common DBPs and are monitored in drinking water worldwide.
questions.learning_content: THMs are a key group of DBPs that can form during water disinfection.
questions.Clue: This group of DBPs is widely tracked in drinking water systems.

questions.question: Which of the following is another major DBP group besides THMs?
questions.explanation: HAAs are another regulated class of DBPs formed during disinfection with chlorine.
questions.learning_content: HAAs are common DBPs, along with THMs.
questions.Clue: These acids form during disinfection, just like THMs.

questions.question: What do both THMs and HAAs have in common?
options: They are formed during water disinfection
questions.correct_answer: They are formed during water disinfection
questions.explanation: Both THMs and HAAs are produced when disinfectants like chlorine react with organic matter.
questions.learning_content: THMs and HAAs are formed by disinfectants reacting with organic materials.
questions.Clue: They’re both created as a result of water treatment.

questions.question: Which of these is the best description of DBP types?
options: Groups of chemicals formed during disinfection
questions.correct_answer: Groups of chemicals formed during disinfection
questions.explanation: DBPs include several chemical groups like THMs and HAAs, formed as by-products of disinfection.
questions.learning_content: DBPs are chemical groups unintentionally created during water treatment.
questions.Clue: Think about what’s created unintentionally while cleaning water.

questions.question: Why are some DBPs grouped into types like THMs and HAAs?
options: To help regulate and monitor them
questions.correct_answer: To help regulate and monitor them
questions.explanation: Grouping DBPs helps scientists and governments monitor and control their presence in water supplies.
questions.learning_content: Grouping DBPs (e.g., THMs, HAAs) helps track and control them in water.
questions.Clue: Labeling things makes it easier for scientists and regulators to keep track.
